comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: That is Cloghvorra. See "The Cause of an Ice Age" by Sir Robert Stawell Ball

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Thank you! So, this is the Cloghvorra Stone written of by Irish scientist, mathematician and astronomer, Robert Stawell Ball. The quote that keeps appearing is: "The problem that first demands solution is to discover the disruptive agent which would be potent enough to rip the Cloghvorra Stone from its parent bed, to bear it down the valley for miles, and to cast it on the mountain side." (p. 3, The Cause of an Ice Age, 1891) But the "problem that [also] demands solution" still is where is it? Have Google Mapped, but in vain...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: There is a limestone boulder, 2,000 tons, at Roughty, two miles south-east of Kenmare (vide Explanation of Sheet, 184, p. 36). This boulder, called ' Cloghvorra,' 26 feet x 16 feet X 15 feet, of limestone lies on old red sandstone, 260 feet above the sea, on the side of a hill half a mile south of Roughty Bridge, having been moved southward. www.ebooksread.com/authors-eng/henry-carvill-lewis/papers...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Have searched every map known to humankind (online) but cannot locate the rock. Thanks to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] we know it's at Roughty. Can't find Roughty on modern maps, though Roughty Bridge appears on OSI Historic Maps. So to my eternal shame, I'm slapping this one down approximately 2 miles south-east of Kenmare, but I am announcing defeat unless some map buff like blackpoolbeach cares to take up the gauntlet... And if any of you suggest that it's because women can't read maps, I'll block you! :D
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: Here's Roughty Bridge on Panoramio (conveniently geotagged) www.panoramio.com/photo/14945910 And no, I'm NOT going to stop and ask for directions.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Cloghvorragh is due East of Kenmare and South-East of Roughty Bridge, so misleading directions from Henry Carvill Lewis. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,493774,570773,7,9 I estimate it is in Geograph square V9370 but there are no photos yet. Hint to locals! www.geograph.ie/gridref/v9370 Google Street View maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=kenmare&hl=en&ll=51.8787...

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] All is now revealed. Cloghvorragh is a secret British radio transmitter. www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2088575/Tinker-Tailor-So...

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I found Cloghvorragh a few days ago on the OSI historic map. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,493774,570773,7,9 Can you update the Yahoo location, please? I spent a pleasant hour navigating the country lanes on Google Street View. Amazingly, Cloghvorragh can be seen through a gap in the hedge.
